pageContext.claim: “Chain migration, you know, that's when you come in and then everybody you've ever met in the history of the world comes in with you, your mother, your grandfather, your cousin, your brother, your aunt, your uncle, any person that ever met you, come on into our country.”
pageContext.analysis: This is rich, considering Trump's mother- and father-in-law recently gained U.S. citizenship through "chain migration." The suggestion that either a U.S. citizen or a green card holder could bring in “virtually unlimited numbers of distant relatives” is an exaggeration to say the least. There are restrictions — citizens can petition for a green card for spouses, children, parents or siblings, while green card holders can only petition for a spouse or unmarried children. Plus, there’s often a lengthy wait list.
